awd_titl_txt: Continuing Innovation in Information Technology:  A Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
The very success of the industries that produce information technology (IT) and the pervasiveness
of their products and services in our daily lives can obscure the mutually reinforcing
roles that industry, government, and academia play in conducting IT research and its translation
into new products, services, and industries. This project will capture examples of such phenomena
as how much industry builds on government-funded university research, the long incubation
periods sometimes needed for research to be translated into major industry activities, the
steady work and funding required to get from initial exploration to large-scale commercial
deployment, the interdependencies between research advances in different subfields, and the
complex nature of the IT research ecology. This project will build on earlier work by
developing additional and/or more in-depth examples and providing updated information
on research impacts and the other phenomena listed above in the context of these examples.

por.por_cntn:
At 2015 workshop organized by a committee of the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, leading academic and industry researchers and industrial technologists described key research and development results and their contributions and connections to new IT products and industries.  

Speaking at the workshop were robotics entrepreneur Rodney Brooks, Internet pioneer Vint Cerf, Pentium microprocessor architect and former DARPA Microsystems Technology Office director Bob Colwell, Stanford professor and wireless entrepreneur Andrea Goldsmith, Carnegie Mellon professor and machine learning and translation expert Jamie Carbonell, Berkeley professor and networked, embedded systems researcher David Culler, networked sensing pioneer and professor at Cornell Tech Deborah Estrin, machine intelligence researcher and distinguished scientist at Microsoft Research Eric Horvitz, Carnegie Mellon provost and former NSF assistant director Farnam Jahanian, sociologist and principal researcher at Microsoft Research Duncan Watts, computer architecture and mobile computing researcher and Princeton professor Margaret Martonosi, wearable computing pioneer and professor at Georgia Tech Thad Starner, and computer security expert and UCSD professor Stefan Savage.

A report (Continuing Innovation in Information Technology: A Workshop Report, National Academies Press, 2016; available for download at http://www.nap.edu/catalog/23393/) was prepared summarizing workshop presentations and discussions. The resulting workshop summary report is organized into five broad themes: (1) fueling the innovation pipeline, (2) building a connected world, (3) advancing the hardware foundation, (4) developing smart machines, and (5) people and computers—and ends with a summary of remarks from the concluding panel discussion. Technical areas explored in the report include the evolution of the Internet, the development of the “Internet of Everything,” the wireless communications future, machine learning and translation, robotics, user-centered design, and wearables.

The narratives provide only a limited sample of the overall IT research ecosystem and cannot capture the full range of challenges, failures, or successes that are inherent to any research field. They do, however, provide compelling illustrations of how academic and industry research has underpinned innovation in IT and has had significant economic and other societal impacts.

Modified by: Jon K Eisenberg
